title: Does it matter whether I live or die considering that life has no meaning? - Quora

response.answer_text: How old are you? That you think Life has no meaning?? What has happened to you in the years you have been living that would leave you feeling this way? Are you expressing yourself, your thoughts, your emotions? Anger is really a hurt person who has not processed or digested what occurs in Life. Anger turned inward, becomes Depression. Don’t fall into that trap of anger, hurt, hurt others, because ultimately, when you hurt others, whether intentionally or not, you end up hurting yourself. Do you not see the true Glory in Life all around You? You have been given the gift of Life, to full-fill Your Soul Path. Life is a both a journey and an adventure. Wake up that amazing inner child in you, with the wonder, the magic, the perfection in Nature, the tastes, sounds and smells. Learn to Daydream again. Be that child again, with the innocence of embracing a new dawn each day. Life is a quarry, out of which we are to mold and chisel and complete a character. –Goethe Accept, Allow, Love, and be compassionate to other souls and yourself. The Love of Self is the Greatest Love of all. When you Love yourself, your heart is open, therefore, allowing Love to flow back to you, in the form of relationship, new job, that you like going to each day. Open yourself up to the Abundance of Life and what it has to offer. Om Mane Padme Om.

The OP asked, “Does it matter whether I live or die considering that life has no meaning?” Whoever told you that life has no meaning is a nihilist — someone who believes that nothing matters. That’s usually a sign they are atheist also. In nihilistic thought, we just happened to exist, to live, and everything exists for no reason other than. it. just. does. Without getting into a theological issue but a philosophical one; there are reasons. Everything exists now because it existed before in a universe in motion, and that means change is constant. In the moment that is *This Instant,* everything and us are different in the way we are because of what the universe and everybody else just did in the moment before. And here’s the kicker: Whatever we’re doing or not doing in this instant (or lifetime) is going to affect how everything else is in all of the remaining instants of our lives and of the universe. Now, you don’t know why, but for most of your entire life, you’ve been feeding yourself for no reason — right? If it were really for no reason, why are you just now wondering why? Why didn’t you starve to death years ago, or at least last Wednesday? It’s because you are programmed to live, and you only get to live once; and what you do in the next instant and the next will affect how you well you could enjoy living in the one after that. The reason for life is (drum roll): While you’re alive, to see how well you can live it. Not necessarily to live big or fast or in the public eye, but hopefully healthy, productive and to leave the world a better place for the kids.

Never believe for a second that any life, your own or everyone else’s, has no meaning! If you’re thinking in terms of whether there’s life after death, immortality, in religious terms, let’s just leave that one alone. No one knows. For all intents and purposes, it’s a matter of belief. So, I’ll keep my comments focused on the simple issue of finding meaning in life by living it every day. In that sense, every life has meaning. It has meaning to oneself, as we go through life, experiencing it every day, growing, increasing in our understanding, gaining perspective, and experiences all the joys and sorrows, triumphs and disappointments, of a life lived to its fullest. Beyond experiencing our own lives, we never can know or understand completely the effect our lives have on others. Sometimes we receive feedback, but often what we’ve said, a kindness we’ve extended to someone else, a moment when we stopped someone from acting in a way that might have damaged another, or some other seemingly small act will have effects that ripple far beyond our immediate experience. Sometimes we hear about them. At others, we never become aware of the good (or potential harm) our actions have had. Maybe eternal life lies in those small kindnesses or inadvertent hurts that rebound through time. Therefore, never consider your life to be or have been without meaning. You never know…..

If your life has no meaning, then it is your fault for not giving it one. This is one of the most basic responsibilities that come with being an sapient being. On the grandest scale, it really doesn't matter if you live or die. On that scale, the universal scale, none of this and none of us matter. At all. But on your scale, you do matter. You (should) matter to yourself and you matter to the people around you. To your friends, your family - especially your children, if you have any -, to all the people whose lives you touch. So get your act together and find meaning for yourself. It doesn't have to be grand or special or last forever. You can find meaning in the smallest, most trivial of things. Your local park is full of trash? Clean it up! Your elderly neighbor can't manage the stairs anymore? Help her out! The single mom next door is on the verge of collapse? Offer to babysit, so she can do something just for herself once in a while. There are a myriad of small ways in which you can positively impact the world and the people around you. There is a plethora of ways to find meaning for oneself. Stop moping and start doing.

you may not know the meaning or purpose your life has but that does not mean it has no meaning or purpose. I can think of three occasions when my just being somewhere had a great impact on someone's life without my planning. Once I found a little boy lost in a department store and ended up restoring him to his mother. Another time I found a toddler on the sidewalk who had wandered out of his backyard and took him home, and the third time I was just standing at the bottom of a staircase when a child fell down and landed on my foot which saved his life as my foot was softer than the floor. ( bad sprain to my toe). My point is your existence can have meaning even without your intention. That said , it would be a good idea to intentionally do things that help others , find some way in your work and daily life where you give to others. Kindness and good deeds give meaning to your life and make your life worthwhile.

I am sorry to hear that you think life has no meaning. I disagree with that statement strongly. My life has a great deal of meaning… to me, and to other people around me. Just because there is no evidence that life has any intrinsic meaning does not mean there is no other kind of meaning that it could have. If there is anyone else who you interact with at all ever, then your life has meaning to them. All the lack of an intrinsic meaning to life means is that you are free: free to give your life whatever meaning you like. Go for it.

We usually ask this question when everything seems to go wrong in our lives. You start to compare your life with those of others. You might feel like many trains are passing and you cant seem to board the right one. All your friends and family seems so far ahead. Other times you're just tired running a race you cant seem to see the end of. It is a bit discouraging. My advice would be to go and spend some regular time in a very peaceful place. Free your mind from this world. Try to focus on all the happy moments in your life. Learn to create new dreams. Exercise a bit. Eat healthy food. Start a new page and forget the upsetting things from the past. Build a new attitude. It is something you need to do for yourself.

You are making a premise of “life has no meaning” and stating it as a fact. Even if you believe that you are only a meat robot and that this is all that there is, even then your life has meaning in that you have experiences and relationships that matter. However if you believe that there is more than this world and that you are a conscious being, then there is a grand scheme, so life has meaning, even if you lived alone in a cave meditating from very young until death.

You are making a classic error in philosophy. You are basing your question on a premise that you are stating as a fact that is a thesis at best. You might feel that “life has no meaning,” but there is no universal belief that this is the case. In fact, it’s a minority belief for sure. Once you allow in the possibility that life may have meaning, it very well may matter to you whether you live or die.

A2A You may feel your life has no meaning at this time, but it is not true. You are created in the image of God, and he made you for a reason. I strongly suggest that you repent of your sins, and become born again, see John ch.3.Once you do that God becomes your father and will give you some purpose in life. Read the New Testament and see how God wants you to live. All the best.

does it really not have meaning? Do you want to gamble on there not being a eternity and you going to hell for the sin of destroying a life that was made to fulfil a purpose that was laid out before you by God. Just because you say somethinh is or isnt does noty always make it true.

You'll have to ask the people and animals that you knew and see if your life had no meaning. And no. It doesn't. But you have to have lived long enough to have some kind of impact on the lives around you, but not very long from what I've seen. Sometimes a breif life can have a great impact. Sometimes old men and women die without much of an impact.

‘Meaning’ is relative to the person making the evaluation. Your life is meaningless to the countless people who don’t know you exist (or only know you as you know them, in the most abstract, statistical sense), but is meaningful to both yourself and those who do know you.

I want you to think about what you are saying here, why doesn't your life have meaning? All the memories that you've obviously forgotten or have gone stale in your mind, all cherished moments cast by the wayside? Life has great meaning and you just got a refresher course, I've been where you are and I'm glad I came out of it, find your way out and get back on track, you are important to the world and your loved ones. Best wishes and happy holidays. TY4TQ

Yes it matters. Maybe u r required here for some particular work, someone's happiness. Maybe u can bring change to the society. Surely u can bring change to something. U just need to figure it out. That is wht life is, a fictitious story that u can transform into reality by working on and on. Life has different meanings for everyone. U need to find out yours.
It probably matters to those who care about you. If you really don’t think it matters, you maybe depressed—usually a temporary condition that does not require a permanent solution such as suicide.
If you really believe that last statement…then no, it doesn't matter in the grand scheme. This does not mean that others wouldn't be affected by your death.
Life has the meaning you give it by your thought, speech, and action. You decide.
